On March 5, 2025, the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council, a recognized student organization, filed suit against members of the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents, Chancellor John Sharp, and President Mark A. Welsh III in their official capacities, seeking injunctive relief under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The student organization, represented by the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE), challenged the Board's February 28, 2025 resolution banning drag shows from campus "Special Event Venues."

The dispute arose when the Board abruptly prohibited "Draggieland," an annual student-funded drag show that had been held at the Rudder Theatre for five years and was scheduled for March 27, 2025. The student organization had reserved the venue in May 2024, received approval in October 2024, and sold 168 tickets before the Board held a telephone meeting on February 28, 2025, to adopt its ban. The Board's resolution stated that drag shows involving "biological males dressing in women's clothing" with "exaggerated female makeup" were inconsistent with the university system's values because they "demean women" and "promote gender ideology." The Board cited President Trump's January 20, 2025 executive order entitled "Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government" and concerns about Title IX compliance as justifications for the ban.

Judge Lee H. Rosenthal of the Southern District of Texas held a hearing on March 18, 2025, and issued a preliminary injunction on March 24, 2025, finding that the student organization demonstrated a substantial likelihood of success on its First Amendment claims. The court determined that drag performances constitute protected expressive conduct under the First Amendment and that the Board's ban was unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination that could not survive strict scrutiny. The court found that the Rudder Theatre functions as a designated public forum that had hosted numerous theatrical performances, political speakers, and beauty pageants without restriction. The court rejected the Board's arguments that drag shows could create a hostile environment for women or violate Title IX, noting no evidence of harassment complaints from past Draggieland performances. The court also found the ban unconstitutionally vague for failing to define terms like "vulgar," "sexualized," or "lewd."

The preliminary injunction ordered the Board to permit Draggieland to proceed as scheduled on March 27, 2025, at 7:30 p.m. in the Rudder Theatre, with no bond requirement. The Board filed a notice of appeal to the Fifth Circuit on March 28, 2025, along with a motion to stay the injunction pending appeal, which remains pending. The case continues with an initial pretrial conference scheduled for May 8, 2025, before Judge Rosenthal.

On March 31, 2025, Inclusiv, Inc., a 50-year-old nonprofit organization that partners with credit unions to promote financial security, filed suit against the Environmental Protection Agency, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin, Acting Deputy Administrator W.C. McIntosh, and Citibank, N.A. The nonprofit is represented by private counsel from Venable LLP. The case was assigned to Judge Tanya S. Chutkan and was later consolidated with Case No. 25-cv-698 on April 15, 2025, along with several other related cases involving other Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund grant recipients.

Inclusiv challenges EPA's freeze and attempted termination of its $1.87 billion grant under the Clean Communities Investment Accelerator program, part of the nearly $27 billion Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund established by Congress in the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. Inclusiv brings claims under the Administrative Procedure Act, alleging EPA's actions violate the Inflation Reduction Act, the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, the Anti-Deficiency Act, and EPA's own regulations at 2 C.F.R. §§ 200.339-342. The nonprofit also asserts constitutional violations under the Separation of Powers doctrine (specifically the Legislative Vesting Clause, Spending and Appropriations Clauses, and Take Care Clause) and the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause. Against Citibank, which serves as the financial agent holding the grant funds, Inclusiv brings state law claims for breach of contract, conversion, and replevin. Inclusiv seeks declaratory judgment and injunctive relief.

EPA competitively awarded Inclusiv the grant in April 2024, with a formal grant agreement executed on August 8, 2024, for a performance period running through June 30, 2030. The funds were deposited into an account at Citibank pursuant to a Financial Agency Agreement between Citibank and Treasury and an Account Control Agreement among Inclusiv, Citibank, and EPA. By February 2025, Inclusiv had selected 108 credit union subrecipients across 27 states and Puerto Rico to receive $651 million in subawards for clean energy projects in low- and moderate-income communities.

On February 12, 2025, EPA Administrator Zeldin publicly announced EPA's intention to "return the entire fund balance to the U.S. Treasury," calling the program "criminal." Since mid-February 2025, Inclusiv has been unable to access its funds, as Citibank refused to process disbursement requests despite its ministerial obligations under the Account Control Agreement. On March 11, 2025, Acting Deputy Administrator McIntosh sent termination letters to all GGRF grant recipients, citing unspecified concerns about "program integrity," "fraud, waste, and abuse," and "misalignment with the Agency's priorities." The termination letter did not provide Inclusiv any opportunity to respond or challenge the decision.

Inclusiv filed a motion for preliminary injunction on April 1, 2025, and initially filed an emergency motion for temporary restraining order the same day after discovering its account balance had dropped to zero. The nonprofit withdrew the TRO request on April 2, 2025, after receiving assurances that the funds had been moved into a money market account as part of a monthly process. The Court stayed briefing on the preliminary injunction motion on April 10, 2025, pending resolution of related matters in the consolidated lead case. On April 16, 2025, the Court denied Inclusiv's preliminary injunction motion as moot, referring to a preliminary injunction order issued in the lead case.

On April 11, 2025, five F-1 visa holders - three current students and two post-graduate Optional Practical Training (OPT) workers in the Northern District of California - filed suit against Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem, ICE Acting Director Todd M. Lyons, San Francisco ICE Acting Field Office Director Moises Becerra, and President Donald J. Trump in their official capacities. The plaintiffs, proceeding under pseudonyms S.Y., Z.D., Y.W., H.G., and W.X., are represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP.

The case arose from a widespread pattern beginning April 4, 2025, in which ICE's Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) terminated the Student and Exchange Visitor Information Systems (SEVIS) records of hundreds of F-1 students nationwide. Between April 4 and April 8, 2025, each plaintiff received notice that their SEVIS record had been terminated with the reason listed as "Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status – Individual identified in criminal records check and/or has had their visa revoked." Three plaintiffs also received notices from the State Department that their F-1 visas had been revoked.

The plaintiffs brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging that the SEVIS terminations were unauthorized, arbitrary and capricious, and violated due process under the Fifth Amendment. They argued that none of them had violated their F-1 status requirements - two plaintiffs had minor misdemeanor convictions that were not crimes of violence, two had arrests without convictions, and one had a prior deportation for which they had received a waiver and subsequently been granted a new visa. The plaintiffs contended that under federal regulations, these circumstances did not constitute grounds for terminating their SEVIS records or F-1 status.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent enforcement actions, arrest, detention, transfer, or removal based on the SEVIS terminations. They argued that terminating SEVIS records effectively strips students of their ability to continue their studies or OPT employment, as the DHS website indicates that SEVIS termination results in loss of employment authorization and triggers potential ICE enforcement action.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Noel Wise but was reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White on April 22, 2025, after being found related to another case, Doe v. Trump. On April 17, 2025, Judge Wise granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, finding they had shown serious questions on the merits and likelihood of irreparable harm. The TRO enjoined defendants from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring the plaintiffs and from imposing any legal effect from the SEVIS terminations. This TRO was extended by Judge White on April 25, 2025.

Following briefing and hearings, Judge White granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on May 22, 2025, maintaining the same protections. The court found that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA claims that the SEVIS terminations were not in compliance with federal regulations and were arbitrary and capricious. The government filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025 (Case No. 25-4523) and subsequently moved to stay the injunction pending appeal on August 8, 2025.

The case highlighted a broader pattern of SEVIS terminations affecting international students at universities across California and the nation, including the University of California system and Stanford University, creating significant uncertainty for schools and students about the basis and consequences of these administrative actions.

On April 29, 2025, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), its Board of Directors, and three individual Board members filed suit against President Trump and other executive branch officials challenging the President's attempt to remove three of the Board's five members. The case arose when Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel Trent Morse sent an email on April 28, 2025, stating "on behalf of President Donald J. Trump" that the positions of Board members Laura Ross, Thomas Rothman, and Diane Kaplan were "terminated effective immediately." The plaintiffs were represented by the private law firm Saul Ewing LLP.

The plaintiffs brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution, alleging violations of the separation of powers doctrine, the Presentment Clause, the Appropriations Clause, and the Take Care Clause of the Constitution. They sought declaratory judgment that the termination email was legally ineffective and injunctive relief prohibiting defendants from interfering with CPB's governance and operations.

CPB was established by Congress through the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 as a nonprofit corporation explicitly designated as not being "an agency or establishment of the United States Government." The Act provides that Board members are not "officers or employees of the United States" and prohibits any federal department, agency, officer, or employee from exercising "any direction, supervision, or control" over the Corporation. While the President appoints the nine Board members with Senate confirmation, the Act contains no express provision authorizing presidential removal of Board members. The only removal mechanism specified in the Act is forfeiture of membership for failing to attend at least 50% of Board meetings in a calendar year.

The plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order on April 29, 2025, which the parties later agreed to treat as a motion for preliminary injunction. Judge Randolph D. Moss of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia held a hearing on May 14, 2025. Following the President's removal attempt, a member of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) contacted the two remaining Board members about "getting a DOGE team assigned to the organization," heightening concerns about government interference.

On June 8, 2025, Judge Moss issued a memorandum opinion denying the preliminary injunction. The court found that plaintiffs had not demonstrated likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm. The court analyzed the interaction between the Public Broadcasting Act and D.C. nonprofit corporation law, which permits removal of directors by the appointing authority unless the corporation's articles or bylaws provide otherwise. Notably, CPB's bylaws did not address removal at the time of the President's action, though the Board amended them on May 15, 2025, to require a two-thirds Board vote to confirm any removal. The court concluded that D.C. law permitting removal was not clearly inconsistent with the Act and that CPB could continue functioning through a "designated body" provision even with only two directors.

The parties subsequently agreed to an expedited summary judgment schedule running through October 2025. However, both Laura Ross and Thomas Rothman voluntarily dismissed their claims in July and August 2025, respectively, leaving only the Corporation, the Board, and Diane Kaplan as plaintiffs pursuing the declaratory and injunctive relief claims.

On April 7, 2025, Harry Wiley, a coal miner with 38 years of experience who had been diagnosed with black lung disease, filed a class action lawsuit against the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Department of Health and Human Services, represented by Petsonk PLLC, Mountain State Justice Inc., and Appalachian Mountain Advocates. The case challenged the defendants' termination of nearly all employees at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) Respiratory Health Division in Morgantown, West Virginia, which effectively shut down the Coal Workers Health Surveillance Program (CWHSP) that Congress mandated in the Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977.

The plaintiff brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706), alleging the agency action was arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law, as well as a Fifth Amendment due process claim. The lawsuit sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief compelling the defendants to restore the Respiratory Health Division and continue providing the statutorily required health surveillance and job transfer programs under 30 U.S.C. § 843.

The factual basis centers on NIOSH's statutory obligation to screen coal miners for black lung disease and issue "Part 90" determinations that allow miners with evidence of pneumoconiosis to transfer to low-dust jobs without loss of pay. On April 1, 2025, the defendants issued Reduction in Force (RIF) notices to most Respiratory Health Division employees, placing them on administrative leave pending termination dates of June 2 and July 2, 2025. This action halted all CWHSP operations, leaving miners unable to obtain screenings or Part 90 determinations necessary to protect their health.

Mr. Wiley, diagnosed with black lung in November 2024 by a local clinic and the West Virginia Occupational Pneumoconiosis Board, submitted medical documentation to NIOSH seeking a Part 90 determination but received no response after the program shutdown. Without this determination, he continues working in dusty conditions that will cause his disease to progress. The proposed class includes all coal miners with evidence of pneumoconiosis seeking Part 90 eligibility.

On May 7, 2025, Judge Irene C. Berger held a hearing on the plaintiff's motion for preliminary injunction, receiving testimony from NIOSH employees, miners, and program coordinators about the specialized nature of the black lung screening program and the irreparable harm to miners from its closure. The court found that approximately 5,000 radiographs were processed in fiscal year 2024, and that the highly specialized work could not be transferred to other agencies or employees without extensive training.

On May 13, 2025, Judge Berger granted the preliminary injunction, finding the plaintiff likely to succeed on the merits of his APA claims. The court ordered that the RIFs be enjoined and rescinded to facilitate full restoration of the NIOSH Respiratory Health Division, including health surveillance through the CWHSP and the job transfer program. The court specifically ordered that in the event of any reorganization, there must be no pause, stoppage, or gap in the protections and services mandated by Congress. The Secretary was ordered to submit written certification of compliance within twenty days. The court set security for the injunction at zero dollars, finding no meaningful harm to the defendants and high likelihood of plaintiff's success on the merits. The case remains pending with trial scheduled for May 4, 2026.

On May 17, 2025, Darwin Antonio Arevalo Millan, a Venezuelan citizen detained at the Desert View Annex facility associated with the Adelanto ICE Processing Center, filed a habeas corpus petition and class action complaint challenging his detention and potential removal under Presidential Proclamation No. 10903. The petitioner, represented by private attorney Joshua Jonathan Schroeder, brought suit against President Donald J. Trump, Attorney General Pamela Bondi, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem, and other federal officials, asserting claims under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and raising constitutional challenges under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. The case sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent removal without adequate notice and process.

The Proclamation, issued on March 14, 2025, invoked the Alien Enemies Act (50 U.S.C. §§ 21 et seq.) for only the fourth time in U.S. history, authorizing the immediate detention and removal of Venezuelan nationals allegedly affiliated with Tren de Aragua, which the President designated as a foreign terrorist organization conducting "irregular warfare" against the United States. The petitioner, an asylum applicant who had previously been granted parole to work and reside in the United States pending his asylum proceedings, was arrested during a routine ICE check-in without prior notice or documentation of the arrest basis. He was allegedly told his detention related to his Venezuelan nationality and tattoos that might indicate gang affiliation, though he maintained they were basketball-related.

Judge John W. Holcomb granted a temporary restraining order on May 19, 2025, and certified a class for limited purposes consisting of all noncitizens in custody in the Central District of California subject to the Proclamation. Following a hearing on May 30, 2025, the court issued a preliminary injunction on June 2, 2025, enjoining the government from removing or transferring class members out of the district under the Alien Enemies Act pending further court order regarding adequate notice requirements. The court required a nominal $1 bond.

The court found the petitioner likely to succeed on his due process claims, noting that detainees subject to removal under the Alien Enemies Act are entitled to notice and opportunity to challenge their removal, as established by the Supreme Court's decisions in Trump v. J.G.G. and A.A.R.P. v. Trump. While the court rejected challenges to the President's invocation of the Alien Enemies Act itself, finding such determinations within executive discretion, it held that constitutional due process protections still apply to removal proceedings under the Act.

A dispute arose regarding the basis for the petitioner's continued detention after he was granted asylum on June 9, 2025. The petitioner filed an emergency application for habeas corpus on June 14, 2025, seeking immediate release, but the court denied it on June 20, 2025, finding the government could detain him pending appeal of the asylum grant under 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(2)(A). The government filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on August 1, 2025, challenging the preliminary injunction order, with the appeal assigned docket number 25-4866.

On May 22, 2025, Shira Perlmutter, the Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office, filed suit challenging her purported removal by President Donald J. Trump. The case arose after President Trump fired Librarian of Congress Carla D. Hayden on May 8, 2025, reportedly over concerns about diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives. Two days later, on May 10, the White House Presidential Personnel Office, through Deputy Director Trent Morse, terminated Perlmutter's position "effective immediately." The timing followed one day after the Copyright Office issued a pre-publication report on copyright and artificial intelligence. President Trump then purported to appoint Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche as acting Librarian of Congress without Senate confirmation, and Blanche designated Associate Deputy Attorney General Paul Perkins as acting Register of Copyrights. When Justice Department officials attempted to access the Library of Congress on May 12 to assume these positions, Library staff contacted the U.S. Capitol Police, and the officials left voluntarily.

Perlmutter, represented by the Democracy Forward Foundation and the law firm Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP, sued President Trump in his official capacity, Blanche, Perkins, the White House Presidential Personnel officials (Sergio Gor and Trent Morse), and the Executive Office of the President. She brought two ultra vires claims arguing that the President's actions violated both constitutional and statutory authority. First, she contended that the President cannot appoint an acting Librarian of Congress because the Library is not an "Executive agency" under the Federal Vacancies Reform Act (5 U.S.C. § 3345), and therefore the President lacks authority to make temporary appointments there. Second, she argued that her removal violated the Appointments Clause and separation of powers principles because Congress vested the appointment and removal power for the Register of Copyrights exclusively in the Librarian of Congress under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a), not in the President.

Perlmutter sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent her removal and the defendants from exercising the powers of their claimed positions. She immediately moved for a temporary restraining order on May 22, which Judge Timothy J. Kelly denied on May 28, 2025, finding she had not established irreparable harm. She then filed a motion for preliminary injunction on June 10, which the court similarly denied on July 30, 2025. In a detailed memorandum opinion, Judge Kelly concluded that Perlmutter failed to demonstrate the "genuinely extraordinary situation" required under Sampson v. Murray for preliminary relief in government personnel cases. The court found that her temporary loss of a "statutory right to function," her inability to perform statutory duties, and alleged institutional harms to the Library and Copyright Office did not constitute irreparable harm sufficient to warrant an injunction, particularly given the balance of equities and the government's traditional latitude in personnel matters.

Following the denial of her preliminary injunction motion, Perlmutter filed a notice of appeal to the D.C. Circuit on July 31, 2025, and moved for an injunction pending appeal on August 4. Judge Kelly denied this motion as well on August 20, 2025, reiterating that she had not shown irreparable harm. The case remains pending with cross-motions for summary judgment scheduled for hearing on November 4, 2025, while the appeal proceeds in the D.C. Circuit under case number 25-5285.

On April 20, 2023, the parents of a student and a school district employee filed this civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Sweetwater County School District #1 Board of Trustees and four individual district officials: the Superintendent, Assistant Superintendent/HR Director, Director of Student Services, and a high school principal. The parents were represented by private counsel from Bailey Stock Harmon Cottam Lopez LLP and the Child & Parental Rights Campaign.

The parents alleged violations of their fundamental parental rights under the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause and their right to free exercise of religion under the First Amendment. The mother, who was also employed as a math teacher in the district, additionally claimed violations of her free exercise and free speech rights under the First Amendment. The parents sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, and monetary damages.

The case arose from the school district's implementation of two related policies. The first, termed the "Preferred Names Policy," required district staff to address students by their preferred names and pronouns, including those associated with the opposite sex. The second, the "Parent Concealment Policy," directed staff to withhold information about students' gender identity assertions from parents unless the student consented to disclosure. 

The factual basis centered on the parents' 16-year-old daughter, who had experienced childhood trauma and was diagnosed with ADHD, PTSD, and symptoms of gender dysphoria, for which she was receiving treatment from a private counselor chosen by the parents. During the 2021-2022 school year, unbeknownst to the parents, their daughter requested to be treated as a boy with a male name and male pronouns at school, and asked that this information be concealed from her parents. District staff complied with these requests for over six months, deliberately using the student's legal name and female pronouns when communicating with parents while using male identifiers at school. The mother discovered this concealment only by accident in March 2022 during a conversation with teachers from her daughter's school. When the parents objected and directed the school to use their daughter's legal name and female pronouns, district officials stated they would continue following the student's wishes rather than the parents' directions.

On June 30, 2023, Judge Scott W. Skavdahl issued an order granting in part and denying in part the parents' motion for preliminary injunction. The court enjoined the district from preventing employees from responding to parents' inquiries about their children's requested names or pronouns and from requiring employees to lie about such requests, absent reasonable concerns of physical abuse or harm. However, the court denied the preliminary injunction as to other aspects of the policies.

The parents filed an amended complaint on July 20, 2023. On December 18, 2023, the court ruled on the defendants' motion to dismiss, holding that the parents could not proceed with claims for declaratory and injunctive relief on their parental rights and religious freedom claims but could pursue nominal and compensatory damages. The court dismissed the mother's free speech claim but allowed her free exercise claim as an employee to proceed.

On April 28, 2025, Judge Skavdahl granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on all remaining claims, dismissing the father from the action entirely and granting judgment in favor of defendants against the mother on all her claims. The court entered final judgment the same day. On May 23, 2025, the parents filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, which assigned the case appeal number 25-8027.

On May 10, 2016, seven current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority filed a class action lawsuit against the housing authority and its current and former executive directors, alleging rampant racial discrimination and family status discrimination at the McBride and Elmwood public housing developments in Cairo, Illinois. The plaintiffs, represented by the Hughes Socol law firm and the Sargent Shriver National Center on Poverty Law, brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging violations of the Fair Housing Act, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Illinois Civil Rights Act of 2003. They sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, and monetary damages. The case was assigned to Chief Judge Michael J. Reagan with referral to Magistrate Judge Reona J. Daly.

The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA engaged in a pattern and practice of segregating its public housing developments by race, with approximately 97% of McBride and Elmwood residents being African-American, while white households predominated in other ACHA developments including Connell Smith. This occurred despite African-Americans comprising only 36% of Alexander County's population and despite a 1974 Department of Justice lawsuit that had previously addressed ACHA's racial segregation. The complaint detailed severe maintenance failures at the predominantly African-American developments, including infestations of mice, roaches, and bedbugs; mold; and serious plumbing, heating, and electrical deficiencies, while the Connell Smith development was adequately maintained with security cameras and guards. The plaintiffs also alleged that ACHA prohibited families with children from living in certain developments to prevent African-American families from living in majority-white buildings. Supporting these allegations, on September 30, 2014, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development had issued findings that ACHA violated Title VI through intentional racial segregation at McBride and Elmwood, and HUD ultimately took over ACHA's operations in February 2016.

The plaintiffs filed three amended complaints between July 2016 and February 2017, ultimately expanding to 35 named plaintiffs while dropping initial rent overcharge claims to focus on the discrimination claims and adding state law claims for breach of residential leases, negligence, and willful and wanton conduct. The defendants were narrowed to ACHA, James Wilson (Executive Director from 1989-2013), and Martha Franklin (Executive Director from April 2013-January 2015), with defendants Thomas Upchurch and Joanne Pink voluntarily dismissed in September 2016 and January 2017. Settlement negotiations began in earnest in 2017, with multiple settlement conferences held before Magistrate Judge Daly between February and June 2017. During this period, counsel withdrew from representing three plaintiffs (LaTonya Lee, Denieshia Childress, and Coretta Cornelius) in April and May 2017 after being unable to maintain contact with them.

On July 27, 2017, the represented plaintiffs filed a stipulation dismissing their claims against all defendants with prejudice and without costs, with each party bearing its own attorneys' fees. The three unrepresented plaintiffs failed to respond to court orders about proceeding with their claims, and on September 12, 2017, Chief Judge Reagan dismissed their claims for failure to prosecute and approved the voluntary dismissal of the represented plaintiffs' claims, closing the case without trial.

In September 2017, the United States Department of Justice initiated an investigation of the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice's Broad River Road Complex (BRRC), the state's long-term secure facility for adjudicated youth, under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act. The investigation, conducted by the Civil Rights Division and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of South Carolina, examined whether the facility failed to protect youth from violence and subjected them to prolonged isolation.

Following extensive document review, facility tours, and interviews with staff and youth, DOJ issued findings letters in February 2020 and April 2022 concluding there was reasonable cause to believe BRRC violated the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The investigation found a pattern of constitutional violations including failure to protect youth from youth-on-youth violence, excessive force by staff, and punitive and prolonged isolation. Between July 2018 and May 2019, the facility averaged just over 100 youth but reported 134 fights and 71 assaults resulting in 99 injuries. Staff used dangerous tactics including choking, punching, and applying excessive restraints, often in response to verbal non-compliance rather than physical threats. The facility routinely isolated youth for minor infractions such as using profanity or being "out of place," with some youth spending 40-57% of their time in isolation cells—8x8 foot concrete rooms where youth remained alone 23 hours per day without meaningful education or programming.

On April 14, 2022, the United States filed suit against the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice seeking injunctive relief under 34 U.S.C. § 12601 to remedy the constitutional violations at BRRC. That same day, the parties filed a comprehensive settlement agreement and joint motion to dismiss. The settlement requires DJJ to implement substantial reforms over five years, including conducting a staffing study and implementing appropriate staffing patterns, improving video surveillance coverage, providing structured rehabilitative programming, establishing a positive behavior management system with assistance from consultants, revising use of force policies to limit force to situations of serious and immediate danger, restricting isolation to youth who pose serious and immediate danger after de-escalation efforts fail, creating specialized housing for vulnerable youth, and developing a quality assurance system to track and address incidents. A jointly-selected Subject Matter Expert will monitor compliance and provide reports every six months. The agreement allows for termination after five years if DJJ achieves and maintains substantial compliance for one year. Judge Mary Geiger Lewis granted the joint motion to dismiss on April 20, 2022, with the court retaining jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement if necessary.

On May 21, 2025, a federal grand jury in the Middle District of Tennessee indicted Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia on two counts of human smuggling: conspiracy to unlawfully transport illegal aliens for financial gain in violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324(a)(1)(A)(v) and (B)(i), and illegal transportation of illegal aliens for financial gain in violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324(a)(1)(A)(ii) and (B)(i). The second count arose from a November 30, 2022 traffic stop by Tennessee Highway Patrol where Abrego was driving a vehicle containing nine passengers.

Abrego's arrest occurred under unusual circumstances. He had been living in the United States with his family for over a decade when he was removed to El Salvador on March 15, 2025. The United States Supreme Court subsequently found this removal improper in Noem v. Abrego Garcia, 145 S. Ct. 1017 (2025), and ordered the government to facilitate his return. Following his return and the indictment, federal authorities arrested Abrego on June 6, 2025.

The government immediately sought pretrial detention, arguing that the offenses involved minor victims under 18 U.S.C. § 3142(f)(1)(E), that Abrego posed a serious flight risk, and that he presented a danger to the community. The government's case relied heavily on testimony from Homeland Security Agent Peter Joseph, who recounted statements from cooperating witnesses—including two men who were themselves involved in the alleged smuggling conspiracy and were closely related family members. These cooperators claimed Abrego transported undocumented individuals for payment of $1,000-$1,500 per trip as part of a smuggling business called "Trans Express," and that he sometimes transported minors and brought his own children on smuggling trips. The government also presented evidence from the November 2022 traffic stop, including a handwritten roster suggesting one passenger might have been a minor, though the handwriting was ambiguous and could have indicated either a 2001 or 2007 birth year.

Magistrate Judge Barbara D. Holmes held extensive hearings on June 13, 2025, and issued a detailed 51-page opinion on June 22, 2025, denying the government's detention motion. The court found the government failed to demonstrate by a preponderance of evidence that the case involved minor victims, noting significant reliability problems with the cooperating witnesses' testimony—including their substantial incentives to cooperate (early release from prison, deferred deportation) and evolving statements that grew more incriminating over time. The court also found insufficient evidence of flight risk or danger to the community.

The government appealed to District Judge Waverly D. Crenshaw, Jr., seeking revocation of the release order. After additional briefing and an evidentiary hearing on July 16, 2025, where Agent Joseph provided supplemental testimony, Judge Crenshaw issued a 37-page opinion on July 23, 2025. While finding the government had shown by a preponderance that the crimes involved minor victims (entitling it to a detention hearing), the court agreed with the magistrate judge that the government failed to establish by clear and convincing evidence that Abrego posed such a danger that no conditions could ensure community safety, or by a preponderance that he was likely to flee.

Abrego was initially represented by the Federal Public Defender's office (Dumaka Shabazz, William Allensworth, and Richard Tennent) but later retained private counsel, including attorneys Sean Hecker, Jenna Dabbs, and David Patton appearing pro hac vice, with local counsel Rascoe Dean. On August 19, 2025, the defense filed a motion to dismiss for vindictive and selective prosecution, arguing Abrego was targeted for prosecution in retaliation for his successful Supreme Court challenge to his removal. On August 22, 2025, the court issued a release order with extensive conditions, including location monitoring, travel restrictions to Maryland and necessary trips to Tennessee, and supervision by a third-party custodian. Trial is scheduled for January 27, 2026, before Judge Crenshaw.

On July 1, 2025, three city governments (Columbus, Baltimore, and Chicago), along with Doctors for America (a nonprofit organization of over 27,000 physicians and medical trainees) and Main Street Alliance (a network of approximately 30,000 small businesses), filed suit against Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in his capacity as Secretary of Health and Human Services, HHS, Mehmet Oz as CMS Administrator, and CMS. The plaintiffs, represented by Democracy Forward Foundation, challenged the "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability Rule" published on June 25, 2025, which was set to take effect on August 25, 2025.

The plaintiffs brought their challenge under the Administrative Procedure Act, arguing that multiple provisions of the Rule were both contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious. The Rule purported to address fraudulent and improper enrollments in ACA marketplace plans that had allegedly increased during the temporary expansion of subsidies during COVID-19.
