The complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the NYPD to reform its policies, training, supervision, monitoring, and disciplinary procedures regarding stops and frisks.

Following a seven-day evidentiary hearing in October and November 2012 before Judge Shira A. Scheindlin, the court granted a preliminary injunction on January 8, 2013 (amended February 14, 2013). The court found that plaintiffs had shown a clear likelihood of proving that the City displayed deliberate indifference toward a widespread practice of unconstitutional trespass stops outside TAP buildings in the Bronx. On February 11, 2013, the court certified a class of all individuals who have been or are at risk of being stopped outdoors within the vicinity of Bronx TAP buildings without legal justification. On August 12, 2013, Judge Scheindlin issued a remedial order in conjunction with the related Floyd v. City of New York case, appointing Peter L. Zimroth as an independent monitor and ordering comprehensive reforms including new policies, training programs, supervision procedures, and a pilot program for body-worn cameras.

The City appealed these orders, leading to significant appellate intervention. On October 31, 2013, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals stayed the district court's orders and, citing concerns about the appearance of impartiality, reassigned the case from Judge Scheindlin to a new district judge to be chosen randomly. The case was subsequently assigned to Judge Analisa Torres. Several NYPD police unions - including the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Detectives' Endowment Association, Lieutenants Benevolent Association, and Captains Endowment Association - attempted to intervene in the case to continue the City's appeal after newly-elected Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the City's intention to withdraw its appeals and settle the cases. On July 30, 2014, Judge Torres denied the unions' motions to intervene as untimely, and the Second Circuit affirmed this decision on October 31, 2014.

The parties reached a comprehensive settlement that was approved by the court on July 19, 2017. The settlement requires the NYPD to adopt specific standards for investigative encounters in and around TAP buildings, including that mere presence in or exit from a TAP building does not constitute reasonable suspicion for a stop. The agreement mandates revision of Patrol Guide procedures, implementation of new training programs, documentation requirements for all stops, and supervisory review of stops for constitutional compliance. Buildings may only be enrolled in TAP if there has been recent criminal activity, and enrollment must be reviewed every six months. The settlement provides for continued monitoring by the independent monitor for up to five years, with the possibility of earlier termination if the City demonstrates substantial compliance with all material aspects of the reforms. The monitor has since filed multiple reports documenting the NYPD's progress in implementing required changes to policies, training, supervision, and auditing procedures, though noting ongoing challenges with underreporting of stops and ensuring that written policy changes are implemented in practice.
results.PB-CT-0007:
On November 9, 2010, six same-sex couples and one widower from Connecticut, Vermont, and New Hampshire filed suit challenging Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) as a violation of the Fifth Amendment's guarantee of equal protection. The plaintiffs, represented by Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders along with several private law firms, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against multiple federal agencies including the Office of Personnel Management, the Social Security Administration, and the U.S. Postal Service.

The plaintiffs were all legally married under their respective state laws but were denied various federal benefits because DOMA defined "marriage" for all federal purposes as only between one man and one woman. The specific harms included denial of federal employee health benefits, Family Medical Leave Act protections, Social Security survivor benefits, qualified preretirement survivor annuities under ERISA-governed pension plans, joint tax filing status, and Medicare cost supplements through state retirement systems. For example, Joanne Pedersen, a retired federal employee, could not add her wife Ann Meitzen to her federal health insurance plan, while Gerald Passaro was denied both survivor benefits from his deceased husband's pension plan and the Social Security lump-sum death benefit.

DOMA had been enacted in 1996 in response to Hawaii's Baehr v. Lewin decision, which threatened to allow same-sex marriages. The law affected over 1,138 federal statutes and regulations. Congress justified DOMA based on defending traditional marriage, expressing moral disapproval of homosexuality, protecting state sovereignty, and preserving federal resources.

A significant procedural development occurred in February 2011 when Attorney General Eric Holder notified Congress that the Department of Justice would no longer defend DOMA's constitutionality, though it would continue to enforce the law pending judicial resolution. The Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group of the House of Representatives intervened to defend the statute's constitutionality.

On July 31, 2012, Judge Vanessa L. Bryant of the District of Connecticut granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied BLAG's motion to dismiss. The court conducted an extensive analysis of whether sexual orientation constitutes a suspect or quasi-suspect class, examining factors including the history of discrimination against gay and lesbian individuals, whether sexual orientation affects ability to contribute to society, the immutability of sexual orientation, and the political power of the class. While the court concluded that heightened scrutiny was warranted, it ultimately applied rational basis review and still found DOMA unconstitutional.

The district court systematically rejected every justification offered for DOMA. It found no rational relationship between denying federal benefits to married same-sex couples and the goals of defending traditional marriage, promoting responsible procreation, ensuring children have parents of both sexes, defending traditional morality, preserving government resources, or maintaining uniformity in federal benefits administration. The court noted that DOMA actually created complexity and inconsistency rather than uniformity by requiring the federal government to identify and exclude same-sex marriages from federal recognition.

Following the district court's judgment on August 2, 2012, both the federal defendants and BLAG appealed to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, where the case was docketed as No. 12-3273. Multiple parties subsequently filed petitions for writs of certiorari before judgment with the Supreme Court, seeking expedited review of this significant constitutional question alongside other pending DOMA challenges.
results.PC-AL-0034:
On May 28, 2015, the United States filed a civil rights enforcement action against the State of Alabama and the Alabama Department of Corrections concerning conditions at the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women. The case was brought under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, alleging violations of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The lawsuit was assigned to Judge Myron H. Thompson in the Middle District of Alabama. The United States was represented by attorneys from the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division, Special Litigation Section, along with the U.S. Attorney's Office, while the defendants were represented by in-house counsel from the Alabama Department of Corrections.

The lawsuit followed a Department of Justice investigation that began in February 2013 and concluded with findings issued in January 2014. The investigation revealed a pattern and practice of sexual abuse and sexual harassment of women prisoners by correctional staff at Tutwiler. The DOJ found that for nearly two decades, Tutwiler staff had sexually abused and harassed women prisoners with impunity, including rape, sodomy, sexual assault, fondling, exposure, coerced oral sex, and voyeurism. Staff created a toxic, sexualized environment where prisoners were compelled to submit to sexual advances to obtain basic necessities or avoid punishment. The investigation documented that at least 36 percent of staff had engaged in sexual misconduct with prisoners. Despite having knowledge of these conditions for over eighteen years, including from a prior 1995 DOJ investigation, prison officials had failed to take reasonable steps to protect the women in their custody.

Rather than proceed to litigation, the parties negotiated a comprehensive settlement agreement that was filed simultaneously with the complaint on May 28, 2015. The court entered the settlement as a consent decree on June 18, 2015, conditionally dismissing the complaint without prejudice while retaining jurisdiction to enforce the agreement. The settlement required the State to implement sweeping reforms to ensure constitutional conditions at Tutwiler, including full compliance with the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA) standards, development of gender-responsive policies and procedures, improved staffing and recruitment of female officers, comprehensive staff training, enhanced camera surveillance systems, an inmate grievance system, improved classification procedures, and regular data collection and quality improvement measures.

The agreement provided for an independent monitor to assess compliance, with Jennie Lancaster initially appointed in September 2015, followed by Kathleen Dennehy who assumed the role in August 2016. The monitors conducted regular compliance visits and filed detailed reports with the court every six months. Through eight compliance reports filed between February 2016 and August 2019, the monitors documented steady progress in implementing the required reforms. By the eighth report in August 2019, ADOC and Tutwiler had achieved substantial compliance with 41 of 43 settlement provisions, with only staffing levels and one classification-related provision remaining in partial compliance. The monitoring reports documented significant improvements including implementation of comprehensive PREA policies, staff training on gender-responsive approaches, installation of a state-of-the-art camera system, development of new gender-responsive programming, and creation of accountability systems for addressing sexual abuse allegations. While challenges remained, particularly regarding chronic understaffing of correctional officers, the facility had undergone substantial transformation from the conditions that prompted federal intervention.
results.ED-MI-0001:
On November 8, 2006, the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action (BAMN), along with numerous student and organizational plaintiffs, filed a federal lawsuit challenging Michigan's Proposal 2, a voter-approved constitutional amendment that had passed the previous day by a 58-42% margin. The amendment, which became Article I, Section 26 of the Michigan Constitution, prohibited state institutions, including public universities, from granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public employment, education, and contracting. The plaintiffs sued Governor Jennifer Granholm and the governing boards of Michigan's three major public universities, asserting that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and federal civil rights statutes. The Michigan Attorney General intervened as a defendant on December 14, 2006.

On December 19, 2006, a separate group of University of Michigan faculty members and students, known as the Cantrell plaintiffs and represented by the ACLU and other counsel, filed a similar challenge focusing on a "political restructuring" theory under the Equal Protection Clause. They argued that Proposal 2 unconstitutionally restructured Michigan's political process by requiring racial minorities to seek a constitutional amendment to restore race-conscious admissions policies, while those seeking other types of admissions preferences could simply lobby university boards or administrators. District Judge David M. Lawson consolidated both cases on January 5, 2007.

The litigation's procedural history proved complex. Initially, the district court issued a preliminary injunction on December 19, 2006, postponing Proposal 2's application to university admissions until July 1, 2007, based on a stipulation among the parties. However, Eric Russell, a white applicant to the University of Michigan Law School, successfully intervened and appealed, leading the Sixth Circuit to stay the injunction on December 29, 2006. Both plaintiff groups moved for class certification in May 2007, though the court ultimately did not rule on these motions before deciding the case on summary judgment.

On March 18, 2008, after extensive discovery, the district court granted summary judgment in favor of the Attorney General, rejecting both plaintiff groups' arguments that Proposal 2 violated equal protection. The court distinguished the case from Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School District No. 1, Supreme Court precedents that had invalidated laws placing special burdens on racial minorities' ability to achieve beneficial legislation through the political process. The district court held that those cases protected minorities from impediments to obtaining "equal treatment" but not from barriers to securing "preferential treatment."

The plaintiffs appealed, and on July 1, 2011, a three-judge panel of the Sixth Circuit reversed, finding Proposal 2 unconstitutional under the Hunter-Seattle political-process doctrine. The panel held that Proposal 2 targeted programs that "inure primarily to the benefit of the minority" and restructured the political process to place special burdens on racial minorities' ability to enact beneficial policies. However, the Sixth Circuit granted en banc review and, on November 15, 2012, reversed the panel decision by an 8-7 vote, upholding Proposal 2's constitutionality.

The Supreme Court granted certiorari and, on April 22, 2014, affirmed the en banc decision in Schuette v. BAMN, though without a majority opinion. Justice Kennedy's plurality opinion, joined by Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, concluded that Michigan voters had the authority to prohibit racial preferences through the democratic process, distinguishing the case from Hunter and Seattle. Justice Scalia, joined by Justice Thomas, concurred in the judgment but argued the political-process doctrine should be overruled entirely. Justice Breyer concurred separately, finding that Proposal 2 did not diminish minorities' political participation since it moved decision-making from unelected administrators to voters. Justices Sotomayor and Ginsburg dissented, arguing that Proposal 2 violated equal protection by restructuring the political process along racial lines.

The case arose against the backdrop of the Supreme Court's 2003 decisions in Gratz v. Bollinger and Grutter v. Bollinger, which had struck down the University of Michigan's undergraduate admissions system but upheld its law school's more limited use of race-conscious admissions. Ward Connerly, who had championed similar measures in California, and Jennifer Gratz, the lead plaintiff in Gratz, mobilized the campaign for Proposal 2. Evidence suggested the signature-gathering process involved methods that "undermined the integrity and fairness of our democratic processes," according to the Sixth Circuit, though the measure ultimately appeared on the ballot and passed. The litigation thus represented the culmination of a decades-long battle over affirmative action in Michigan's public universities, with the plaintiffs unable to prevent the implementation of a constitutional amendment that eliminated race-conscious admissions policies that had been in place since the 1970s.
results.DR-CA-0033:
On August 22, 2005, Maurizio Antoninetti, a paraplegic who uses a wheelchair, filed suit against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. in the Southern District of California, alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA), the California Unruh Civil Rights Act, and California Health & Safety Code provisions. Antoninetti was represented by private attorney Amy B. Vandeveld. The case was initially assigned to Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr. and later transferred to Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz.

The lawsuit arose from Antoninetti's visits to two Chipotle restaurants in San Diego and Encinitas, California. The central issue involved the design of Chipotle's food service areas, where customers move along a line next to food preparation counters to order customized Mexican food items. These counters were separated from the customer line by a 44-inch high wall topped with a transparent sneeze guard, bringing the total height to 46 inches. Since the average eye level of wheelchair users ranges from 43 to 51 inches, Antoninetti could not see over the wall to view the available food ingredients or watch his order being prepared, an experience that Chipotle marketed as integral to dining at its restaurants.

Antoninetti sought injunctive relief requiring Chipotle to lower the walls, as well as monetary damages and attorney's fees. He also raised claims regarding inaccessible parking lots, restrooms, and entrances, though these issues were largely resolved through modifications Chipotle made after the lawsuit was filed. A related class action (Case No. 06cv2671) was filed on December 6, 2006, and the cases were consolidated for discovery purposes only in March 2007.

Following cross-motions for summary judgment in April 2007, the district court issued a partial ruling on June 14, 2007. The court held that ADA Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) Section 7.2(2) regarding sales and service counters applied to the food preparation areas, rather than Section 4.33.3 regarding sight lines in assembly areas as Antoninetti argued. The court found that factual issues remained regarding whether Chipotle's accommodation practices constituted "equivalent facilitation" under the guidelines.

The case proceeded to a four-day bench trial in November-December 2007. On January 10, 2008, the district court issued its findings distinguishing between Chipotle's unwritten accommodation policy in place during Antoninetti's visits and a written "Customers with Disabilities Policy" adopted in February 2007. The court found that while the unwritten policy violated the ADA because it relied on subjective employee judgment, the written policy—which required managers to proactively offer accommodations such as showing food samples in cups or describing items—constituted equivalent facilitation and complied with the ADA. The court awarded Antoninetti $5,000 in statutory damages under the CDPA for five "bona fide" visits but denied damages for three visits made for litigation purposes. Critically, the court denied injunctive relief to lower the walls.

Antoninetti appealed, and on July 26, 2010, the Ninth Circuit reversed key portions of the district court's decision in a published opinion (643 F.3d 1165). The appellate court held that both Chipotle's unwritten and written accommodation policies violated the ADA, finding that the policies did not provide equivalent facilitation because they offered separate and unequal experiences compared to what non-disabled customers enjoyed. The Ninth Circuit remanded with instructions to enter judgment against Chipotle and issue appropriate injunctive relief.

On remand, Antoninetti's death on May 9, 2011, mooted the claim for injunctive relief, as his widow (who was substituted as plaintiff) could not demonstrate future harm. The district court maintained the $5,000 damages award for the five non-litigation visits. The attorneys' fees dispute resulted in multiple proceedings, with the district court ultimately awarding $545,079.05 in fees after the Ninth Circuit's favorable ruling, substantially more than the $136,537.83 initially awarded when Antoninetti was deemed to have achieved only limited success.
results.CJ-FL-0009:
Between June 15 and July 1, 2019, seventeen individuals with felony convictions and three civil rights organizations filed five related lawsuits that were consolidated in the Northern District of Florida, challenging Florida's system for restoring voting rights to former felons. The individual plaintiffs had completed their prison terms and supervision but had outstanding legal financial obligations (LFOs) including fines, fees, costs, and restitution that they claimed they were unable to pay. The organizational plaintiffs were the League of Women Voters of Florida, the Florida State Conference of the NAACP, and the Orange County Branch of the NAACP. The defendants, all sued in their official capacities, included Florida's Governor, Secretary of State, and various county Supervisors of Elections. The plaintiffs were represented by a coalition of civil rights organizations including the ACLU, Campaign Legal Center, NAACP Legal Defense Fund, Brennan Center for Justice, and Southern Poverty Law Center.

The case arose from Florida's Amendment 4, a voter-initiated constitutional amendment passed in November 2018 with 64.55% support, which automatically restored voting rights to most felons "upon completion of all terms of sentence including parole or probation." The amendment excluded those convicted of murder or felony sexual offenses. In May 2019, the Florida Legislature enacted Senate Bill 7066, which defined "completion of all terms of sentence" to include payment of all fines, fees, costs, and restitution imposed as part of the criminal sentence, even if converted to civil liens. The Florida Supreme Court later agreed with this interpretation in an advisory opinion issued January 16, 2020.

The plaintiffs brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging that conditioning the right to vote on payment of LFOs violated the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause (as wealth discrimination against those unable to pay), the Twenty-Fourth Amendment (as an unconstitutional poll tax on fees and costs), the Due Process Clause (both as void for vagueness and denial of procedural due process), the First Amendment, and the National Voter Registration Act. The case was initially assigned to Chief Judge Mark E. Walker, who recused himself on July 17, 2019, with the case then reassigned to Judge Robert L. Hinkle.

After an evidentiary hearing, Judge Hinkle granted a preliminary injunction on October 18, 2019, holding that the State could not prevent the seventeen individual plaintiffs from registering to vote based solely on their inability to pay LFOs they genuinely could not afford. The injunction allowed plaintiffs who asserted inability to pay to register, and those who showed inability to pay to vote. On appeal, a three-judge panel of the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction on February 19, 2020, in Jones v. Governor of Florida, 950 F.3d 795, applying heightened scrutiny and finding the LFO requirement likely violated equal protection as applied to indigent felons.

Judge Hinkle certified a class of all persons eligible to vote but for unpaid LFOs and a subclass of those genuinely unable to pay. After an eight-day trial on the merits, the district court issued a 125-page opinion on May 24, 2020, entering a permanent injunction. The court found that the overwhelming majority of affected felons were genuinely unable to pay their LFOs and would be permanently disenfranchised. The court held that the LFO requirement violated equal protection as applied to those unable to pay and that fees and costs imposed as taxes violated the Twenty-Fourth Amendment. The injunction prohibited enforcement of the LFO requirement against those genuinely unable to pay and against anyone for fees and costs, while allowing the State to require payment of fines and restitution from those able to pay.

The State appealed and successfully petitioned for initial en banc review. On September 11, 2020, the en banc Eleventh Circuit reversed the district court's judgment and vacated the injunction. The en banc court held that rational basis review, not heightened scrutiny, applied to the felon reenfranchisement scheme and that conditioning voting on completion of all terms of sentence, including financial obligations, was rationally related to Florida's legitimate interests. The court also rejected the Twenty-Fourth Amendment claim, holding that fees and costs imposed as part of a criminal sentence are not "taxes" within the meaning of that amendment.

The factual record revealed significant administrative problems with Florida's system. Many felons could not determine what they owed because records were unavailable, incomplete, or inconsistent. Some counties had destroyed older records, while others charged fees just to obtain copies of judgments. The State acknowledged it was unable to determine the amounts owed by many of the plaintiffs despite extensive litigation efforts. Evidence showed that approximately 80% of otherwise-eligible felons had unpaid LFOs, that the Florida Clerk of Courts Association anticipated 83% of all LFOs would remain unpaid due to inability to pay, and that at the time of trial, 85,000 felons had registered to vote but the State had not completed screening any of them for eligibility.
results.CW-CA-0005:
On July 18, 2002, five foster children filed a federal class action lawsuit in the Central District of California against state and county officials responsible for child welfare and health services in California. The plaintiffs—Katie A., Mary B., Janet C., Henry D., and Gary E.—proceeded through next friends (guardian representatives) and were represented by a coalition of legal services organizations including the ACLU of Southern California, Western Center on Law and Poverty, National Center for Youth Law, Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law, and Protection & Advocacy Inc. (now Disability Rights California). The lawsuit was brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the Directors of the California Department of Health Services (later Health Care Services), the California Department of Social Services, Los Angeles County, and the Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services.

The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions of the Medicaid Act, which requires states to provide comprehensive mental health services to Medicaid-eligible children under age 21. They also claimed violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and California constitutional provisions. The complaint described a system where foster children with serious mental health needs were denied necessary services, leading to multiple failed placements, unnecessary institutionalization, and inadequate treatment.

On June 18, 2003, Judge A. Howard Matz certified a statewide class of children in California who: (a) are in foster care or at imminent risk of foster care placement; (b) have a documented mental illness or condition; and (c) need individualized mental health services in home or home-like settings. The class definition specifically included services such as professionally acceptable assessments, behavioral support, case management, family support, crisis support, and therapeutic foster care.

The case proceeded on two tracks. First, the plaintiffs reached a settlement with the Los Angeles County defendants in April 2003, which the court approved on July 16, 2003 after a fairness hearing. This settlement established objectives for providing necessary mental health services to class members in Los Angeles County and created a six-member Advisory Panel to monitor implementation. The settlement required the county to ensure mental health needs were identified and services provided, expand wraparound services, enhance permanency planning, and increase placement stability.

The litigation against the state defendants continued. On March 14, 2006, the district court granted plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, ordering the state to provide wraparound services and therapeutic foster care (TFC) to class members within 120 days. The court found these services fell within California's EPSDT obligations under Medicaid. However, on March 23, 2007, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded, holding that while the state must provide all required component services under EPSDT, it was not necessarily required to provide them in the specific bundled forms of wraparound and TFC programs. The appellate court directed the district court to first determine whether the state was providing all required individual services effectively before considering whether bundling was necessary.

Following years of continued litigation and negotiation, the parties reached a comprehensive settlement with the state defendants in 2011. On December 5, 2011, the court entered a stipulated judgment approving the settlement agreement. The state settlement required development of a Documentation Manual for Intensive Care Coordination (ICC) and Intensive Home Based Services (IHBS), amendments to California's Medicaid State Plan, establishment of a shared management structure between state departments, and creation of a Core Practice Model for delivering mental health services to foster children. The settlement particularly focused on a subclass of children with more intensive needs who required immediate access to mental health services. The court retained jurisdiction through December 2014 to monitor implementation.

Post-settlement implementation proved challenging. The Advisory Panel's reports from 2015 through 2018 documented ongoing concerns about slow progress, underutilization of intensive services, inadequate data systems, and low performance on quality measures. Despite some improvements in staffing and development of Child and Family Team capacity, the Panel found that many foster children continued to experience placement instability, inadequate mental health services, and unnecessary group home placements. The Panel made numerous recommendations for improving service delivery, including ensuring immediacy and intensity of mental health services, improving placement stability, strengthening teaming processes, and enhancing supervision and training.

A Special Master appointed to facilitate implementation reported similar concerns through 2014, noting particular challenges with therapeutic foster care approval from federal authorities and gaps in the mental health data system's ability to track key performance indicators. The court's jurisdiction formally ended in 2015, though monitoring through the Advisory Panel continued for several years to track ongoing compliance efforts. Throughout the litigation, disputes arose over discovery, particularly regarding depositions of named plaintiffs and counsel, which were resolved through protective orders maintaining confidentiality of sensitive information about the foster children involved.
results.PC-VA-0022:
On December 19, 2014, Eric J. DePaola, an inmate proceeding pro se, filed a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Virginia Department of Corrections and numerous prison officials, challenging his prolonged solitary confinement at Red Onion State Prison. The case was initially filed with co-plaintiffs Denis Rivera and Luis Velazquez, but Judge James P. Jones severed the cases on April 8, 2015, creating separate actions for each plaintiff.

DePaola, who was sentenced to 38 years in prison at age 16 for crimes including malicious wounding, use of a firearm, statutory burglary, and abduction, has been held in administrative segregation (solitary confinement) since September 2009, following an incident where he stabbed a prison guard. The injury was non-fatal, but resulted in an additional conviction for malicious wounding. DePaola alleged violations of the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause and the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.

The factual basis of DePaola's claims centered on the harsh conditions of his confinement and the permanence of his segregation status. He described being confined to an 8-by-10-foot cell for 24 hours daily except for three 15-minute showers per week and five hours of weekly recreation in what he called a "dog style cage." The conditions included constant bright lighting, no physical human contact except when being shackled, cavity searches before leaving his cell, and meals eaten alone in his cell. DePaola reported suffering mental deterioration, anxiety, night terrors, physical deterioration, headaches, weight loss, and vision problems from the constant fluorescent lights.

Central to DePaola's constitutional claims was Virginia's Operating Procedure 830.A, which classifies certain inmates as "Intensive Management" (IM) based on their perceived potential for extreme violence. Unlike inmates in "Special Management" (SM) classification who can progress through a Step-Down Program back to general population, IM inmates like DePaola are permanently barred from returning to general population. DePaola's IM designation, based on his 2009 stabbing incident, means he will remain in solitary confinement until his projected release date in 2040—a total of 31 years.

The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on October 13, 2015, which Judge Jones denied on May 18, 2016, allowing DePaola to file an amended complaint. The defendants then moved for summary judgment on July 28, 2016. Despite DePaola's opposition arguing that genuine disputes of material fact existed regarding both his procedural due process and Eighth Amendment claims, Judge Jones granted summary judgment for the defendants on September 28, 2016. DePaola filed a timely notice of appeal on October 6, 2016, and the case proceeded to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals (Case No. 16-7358), where the district court's decision was affirmed on November 22, 2017.
results.CJ-MD-0001:
Vernon Evans, Jr., a death row inmate convicted of two murders in 1984 and re-sentenced to death in 1992, filed a civil rights action on January 19, 2006, against Maryland corrections officials challenging the state's lethal injection protocol. Evans, represented by private counsel from Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP and the Office of the Public Defender, brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that Maryland's execution procedures would violate his Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights against cruel and unusual punishment. Evans did not challenge the constitutionality of his death sentence or lethal injection generally, but rather the specific practices and procedures Maryland employed.

The complaint centered on Maryland's use of a three-drug cocktail consisting of sodium pentothal (an anesthetic), pancuronium bromide (a paralytic agent), and potassium chloride (which stops the heart). Evans alleged that the Division of Correction's protocols created a grave risk that he would suffer excruciating pain during execution due to inadequate anesthesia administration by unqualified personnel, lack of monitoring for anesthetic depth, and potential complications from intravenous access given his history of drug use and compromised veins. Medical experts testified that pancuronium bromide would mask any signs of consciousness while causing suffocation, and potassium chloride would cause agonizing pain if administered to an inadequately anesthetized person. The case revealed that Maryland had experienced problems with at least one prior execution, that of Tyrone Gilliam, where IV lines leaked during the procedure.

On January 20, 2006, Evans filed emergency motions for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to halt his execution scheduled for the week of February 6, 2006. Chief Judge Benson Everett Legg conducted hearings on January 24, 27, and February 1, 2006, with testimony from medical experts including anesthesiologists and trauma physicians. On February 1, 2006, Judge Legg denied both the temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, finding that Evans had not demonstrated the likelihood of success on the merits necessary for preliminary relief. The court also denied Evans's motion for a stay pending appeal on February 2, 2006.

Evans immediately appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which dismissed the appeal as moot on February 15, 2006, after Maryland agreed to stay the execution pending state court proceedings. Simultaneously, Evans and three organizational co-plaintiffs (NAACP, ACLU, and Maryland Citizens Against State Executions) filed a separate action in Baltimore City Circuit Court arguing that the execution protocols constituted regulations that had not been properly adopted under Maryland's Administrative Procedure Act and that specific provisions violated the state's death penalty statute.

In a significant ruling on December 19, 2006, the Maryland Court of Appeals found merit in the administrative law claim, holding that portions of the execution protocol directing the manner of administering lethal injection were ineffective until either adopted as regulations in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act or exempted from those requirements by the Legislature. The court rejected Evans's other claims, including allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel under Wiggins v. Smith and racial discrimination in jury selection under Batson v. Kentucky.

Following the Maryland Court of Appeals decision, the parties engaged in consent motions to delay compliance with court orders while the state worked on adopting proper regulations. The federal case remained stayed, with periodic status reports filed through at least 2012. Throughout the litigation, protective orders were in place to shield the identities of execution team members, and extensive discovery occurred regarding Maryland's execution procedures, training, and personnel qualifications. The case highlighted broader concerns about the administration of lethal injection nationwide and the intersection of medical ethics, constitutional requirements, and state administrative law in capital punishment procedures.
results.CW-DC-0001:
On June 20, 1989, seven children in or at risk of entering the District of Columbia's foster care system filed a class action lawsuit in federal district court against the Mayor and other DC officials responsible for child welfare services. The plaintiffs, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union's Children's Rights Project and other attorneys, brought suit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the District's child welfare system violated their rights under federal statutes including the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 and the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District's Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, and the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The class encompassed approximately 2,500 children in the District's legal or physical custody due to abuse or neglect, as well as thousands more children known to be at risk but not in custody.

After a two-week bench trial in February 1991 before Judge Thomas F. Hogan, during which the court heard extensive testimony and accepted over 1,000 stipulated facts, the court issued a comprehensive 102-page opinion finding the District liable. The court concluded that the District's child welfare system failed to comply with federal law, District law, and constitutional requirements. The evidence revealed systemic failures including uninvestigated abuse reports, excessive worker caseloads, children remaining in "emergency care" for years rather than the mandated 90 days, lack of case planning, inappropriate placements, untrained workers and foster parents, and absence of services to families. Children in the District's foster care remained there an average of nearly five years—more than three times the national average.

Following the liability finding, the parties negotiated an 84-page consent decree that was entered as a Modified Final Order on November 18, 1993, after the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals remanded with instructions to base the order entirely on District law rather than federal law. The order required comprehensive reforms including timely investigations of abuse reports within 48 hours, provision of services to prevent removals, appropriate placements in family-like settings, development of case plans, regular visitation, and numerous other specific requirements. The Center for the Study of Social Policy was appointed as Court Monitor to oversee implementation.

When the District failed to comply with the remedial order, Judge Hogan held the defendants in contempt in May 1995 and imposed a general receivership over the entire child welfare system. The receivership continued until 2001, during which time court-appointed receivers directly managed the system with authority to override local law when necessary to achieve compliance. Even after the receivership ended, the District remained under court supervision with detailed implementation plans setting specific performance benchmarks and deadlines. Limited receiverships were reimposed in certain areas when compliance faltered.

Throughout the case's multi-decade history, monitoring reports documented both progress and persistent challenges. While the number of children in foster care decreased significantly and some standards were met, core problems persisted including untimely investigations, inadequate services to families, inappropriate placements, and lack of permanency planning. As late as 2019, the parties were still negotiating exit and sustainability plans, with the Monitor continuing to assess compliance with remaining requirements thirty years after the initial filing.
